title: Error: Error trying to start business network. Error: Failed to connect to any peer event hubs
body:
My enviourment:
Composer version: v0.20.6
MacOS 10.14.2
Node v8.15.0
npm v6.4.1

 I followed: Step 1: Getting Hyperledger Fabric running and Starting Hyperledger Fabric as per commands and had Hyperledger Fabric and creation of PeerAdminCard went well. 

I was also able to install a .bna file with no errors;
> composer network install -a some-network.bna -c PeerAdmin@hlfv1

✔ Installing business network. This may take a minute...
Successfully installed business network some-network, version 0.0.2-deploy.3
Command succeeded

When I try to start the network utilizing the network 

> composer network start --networkName some-network --networkVersion 0.0.2-deploy.3 -A admin -S adminpw -c PeerAdmin@hlfv1 --file networkadmin.card

I am getting the following errors:

Starting business network hello-network at version 0.0.2-deploy.3

Processing these Network Admins: 
	userName: admin

✖ Starting business network definition. This may take a minute...
Error: Error trying to start business network. Error: Failed to connect to any peer event hubs. It is required that at least 1 event hub has been connected to receive the commit event
Command failed

Please advice.

title: Upgrade to Fabric 1.3
body: Signed-off-by: James Taylor <jamest@uk.ibm.com>

title: Not ready for 1.3.0.
body:
The samples from `hlfv12` work great with HLF v1.3.0 out of the box. That is, until re-generating cryptographic material. After following the `howtobuild.txt` directives, the genesis and channel tx make the whole stack crash.

For example, the `orderer` container complains about an invalid CA:

```
orderer.example.com       | 2018-10-26 19:08:33.375 UTC [orderer/commmon/multichannel] newLedgerResources -> PANI 050 Error creating channelconfig bundle: initializing channelconfig failed: could not create channel Orderer sub-group config: setting up the MSP manager failed: the supplied identity is not valid: x509: certificate signed by unknown authority (possibly because of "x509: ECDSA verification failure" while trying to verify candidate authority certificate "ca.example.com")
orderer.example.com       | panic: Error creating channelconfig bundle: initializing channelconfig failed: could not create channel Orderer sub-group config: setting up the MSP manager failed: the supplied identity is not valid: x509: certificate signed by unknown authority (possibly because of "x509: ECDSA verification failure" while trying to verify candidate authority certificate "ca.example.com")
```

title: Not ready for HLF 1.3.0: `configtx.yaml`.
body:
When generating channel artifacts, recent versions of `configtxgen` (Eg 1.3.0 on go1.10.4) give lots of warnings, possibly breaking:

```
2018-10-26 20:02:57.431 WEST [common/tools/configtxgen] main -> WARN 001 Omitting the channel ID for configtxgen for output operations is deprecated.  Explicitly passing the channel ID will be required in the future, defaulting to 'testchainid'.
2018-10-26 20:02:57.431 WEST [common/tools/configtxgen] main -> INFO 002 Loading configuration
2018-10-26 20:02:57.435 WEST [common/tools/configtxgen/encoder] NewChannelGroup -> WARN 003 Default policy emission is deprecated, please include policy specifications for the channel group in configtx.yaml
2018-10-26 20:02:57.435 WEST [common/tools/configtxgen/encoder] NewOrdererGroup -> WARN 004 Default policy emission is deprecated, please include policy specifications for the orderer group in configtx.yaml
2018-10-26 20:02:57.436 WEST [common/tools/configtxgen/encoder] NewOrdererOrgGroup -> WARN 005 Default policy emission is deprecated, please include policy specifications for the orderer org group OrdererOrg in configtx.yaml
2018-10-26 20:02:57.436 WEST [common/tools/configtxgen/encoder] addSignaturePolicyDefaults -> WARN 006 Specifying AdminPrincipal is deprecated and will be removed in a future release, override the admin principal with explicit policies.
2018-10-26 20:02:57.436 WEST [common/tools/configtxgen/encoder] NewOrdererOrgGroup -> WARN 007 Default policy emission is deprecated, please include policy specifications for the orderer org group Org1 in configtx.yaml
2018-10-26 20:02:57.436 WEST [common/tools/configtxgen/encoder] addSignaturePolicyDefaults -> WARN 008 Specifying AdminPrincipal is deprecated and will be removed in a future release, override the admin principal with explicit policies.
2018-10-26 20:02:57.437 WEST [common/tools/configtxgen] doOutputBlock -> INFO 009 Generating genesis block
2018-10-26 20:02:57.437 WEST [common/tools/configtxgen] doOutputBlock -> INFO 00a Writing genesis block
```

The same happens when generating the channel tx:

```
2018-10-26 20:04:25.974 WEST [common/tools/configtxgen] main -> INFO 001 Loading configuration
2018-10-26 20:04:25.978 WEST [common/tools/configtxgen] doOutputChannelCreateTx -> INFO 002 Generating new channel configtx
2018-10-26 20:04:25.978 WEST [common/tools/configtxgen/encoder] NewApplicationGroup -> WARN 003 Default policy emission is deprecated, please include policy specifications for the application group in configtx.yaml
2018-10-26 20:04:25.978 WEST [common/tools/configtxgen/encoder] NewApplicationOrgGroup -> WARN 004 Default policy emission is deprecated, please include policy specifications for the application org group Org1 in configtx.yaml
2018-10-26 20:04:25.978 WEST [common/tools/configtxgen/encoder] addSignaturePolicyDefaults -> WARN 005 Specifying AdminPrincipal is deprecated and will be removed in a future release, override the admin principal with explicit policies.
2018-10-26 20:04:25.979 WEST [common/tools/configtxgen] doOutputChannelCreateTx -> INFO 006 Writing new channel tx
```

It'd be great to receive directives on how to implement the deprecated "auto-defaults".

title: Invalid `configtx.yaml` file.
body:
Some YML parssers will trip on the fact that the `Profiles` section is declared first while referring to references of sections declared afterward (On my Linux box, it fails as it doesn't know `*OrdererDefaults` and `*ApplicationDefaults`).

The file should be changed to allow such parsers (Eg move the `Profiles` sections all the way to the end of the file.

title: Inconsistent output when re-generating crypto material.
body:
When following the `howtobuild.txt` instructions in the `composer` folder, the output is different in terms of expected number of files.
Some files are missing that might impact running services and make the environment unusable once re-generated:

```
crypto-config/ordererOrganizations/example.com/users/Admin@example.com/tls/server.crt
crypto-config/ordererOrganizations/example.com/users/Admin@example.com/tls/server.key
crypto-config/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/users/Admin@org1.example.com/tls/server.crt
crypto-config/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/users/Admin@org1.example.com/tls/server.key
```

New files that didn't exist before get generated:

```
composer/crypto-config/ordererOrganizations/example.com/msp/admincerts/ca.example.com-cert.pem
composer/crypto-config/ordererOrganizations/example.com/users/Admin@example.com/tls/client.crt
composer/crypto-config/ordererOrganizations/example.com/users/Admin@example.com/tls/client.key
composer/crypto-config/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/msp/admincerts/ca.org1.example.com-cert.pem
composer/crypto-config/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/users/Admin@org1.example.com/tls/client.crt
composer/crypto-config/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/users/Admin@org1.example.com/tls/client.key
```

title: Error in v1.2 of fabric-dev-servers - Missing key/value in fabric-dev-servers/hlfv11/createPeerAdmin.sh
body:
Unfortunately, there is a severe error in the Fabric-Dev-Servers v1.2 for hlfv11 Fabric setups. The error results in the improper creation of DevServer_connection.json, and subsequently causes the `composer card import` for the PeerAdmin@hlfv1 network card to fail. As a result a user can't setup a hlfv11 business network with the new Composer Tools Fabric-Dev-Servers v1.2 download. 

It took some time to track this down, because the error is in a JSON layout inside the createPeerAdmin.sh bash file. It appears there was an omission in v1.2 as Composer Tools v1.1 Fabric-Dev-Servers obviously had the correct code. 

When hlfv11/createPeerAdmin runs the terminal output is:

```
Successfully created business network card file to
        Output file: /tmp/PeerAdmin@hlfv1.card

Command succeeded


Failed to import the business network card
keyword:    required
dataPath:   .peers['peer0.org1.example.com']
schemaPath: #/required
params:
  missingProperty: eventUrl
message:    should have required property 'eventUrl'

Error: Errors found in the connection profile in the card
Command failed

There are no Business Network Cards available.

Command succeeded
```

The eventURL key/value is missing from the DevServer_connection.json cat. 

Beginning on line 123 of hlfv1/createPeerAdmin.sh ...
```
"peers": {
        "peer0.org1.example.com": {
            "url": "grpc://${HOST}:7051",
        }
    },
```

Should be ... 
```
    "peers": {
        "peer0.org1.example.com": {
            "url": "grpc://${HOST}:7051",
            "eventUrl": "grpc://${HOST}:7053"
        }
    },
```

The only work around is to edit the hlfv11/createPeerAdmin.sh

title: Add support for Fabric 1.2

old event hub is no longer used.

title: How to connect to Hyperledger from a different container?
body:
If I am running Node.js app locally, I am able to connect to Hyperledger with connection.json localhost:
```
{"name":"hlfv1","x-type":"hlfv1","x-commitTimeout":300,"version":"1.0.0","client":{"organization":"Org1","connection":{"timeout":{"peer":{"endorser":"300","eventHub":"300","eventReg":"300"},"orderer":"300"}}},"channels":{"composerchannel":{"orderers":["orderer.example.com"],"peers":{"peer0.org1.example.com":{}}}},"organizations":{"Org1":{"mspid":"Org1MSP","peers":["peer0.org1.example.com"],"certificateAuthorities":["ca.org1.example.com"]}},"orderers":{"orderer.example.com":{"url":"grpc://localhost:7050"}},"peers":{"peer0.org1.example.com":{"url":"grpc://localhost:7051","eventUrl":"grpc://localhost:7053"}},"certificateAuthorities":{"ca.org1.example.com":{"url":"http://localhost:7054","caName":"ca.org1.example.com"}}}
```

Now if I am running Node.js app in Docker container, on same Docker network `composer_default` as the peer/orderer/ca, what IP should I be using to connect?

I have tried name of container `http://ca.org1.example.com:7054`, but it gives me error: `Error: Error trying login and get user Context. Error: Error trying to enroll user or load channel configuration. Error: Calling enrollment endpoint failed with error [Error: connect ETIMEDOUT 92.242.140.21:7054]`.

Any advice would be appreciated. Thanks!

title: Error: creating resource error Failed to load connector module "composer-connector-undefined" for connection type "undefined". Cannot find module 'composer-connector-undefined'
body:
Hi, 

I have upgraded to composer v0.19.0 and now when trying to get it connect via node red I do receive the following error: 
`[error] [hyperledger-composer-out:carauction-network] Error: creating resource error Failed to load connector module "composer-connector-undefined" for connection type "undefined". Cannot find module 'composer-connector-undefined'-Cannot find module 'composer-connector-undefined'-Cannot find module 'composer-connector-undefined'-Cannot find module 'composer-connector-undefined'-Cannot find module 'composer-connector-undefined'-Cannot find module 'composer-connector-undefined'-Cannot find module 'composer-connector-undefined'-Cannot find module 'composer-connector-undefined'-Cannot find module 'composer-connector-undefined'-Cannot find module 'composer-connector-undefined'-Cannot find module 'composer-connector-undefined'-Cannot find module 'composer-connector-undefined'-Cannot find module 'composer-connector-undefined'
`

title: Catching Error in Node-Red
body:
Hi,

If composer node is throwing an error like **MVCC_Read_conflict** then it can be seen only on **debug console** in node-red but cannot be captured. If it can be captured then this may be use to re-submit the transaction. 

There may be one solution to this problem. If `node.error(msg)` in composer node-red code can be change to `node.error("Error",msg)` Then already available `catch` node in node-red may be used to capture the error and may be transaction can be re-submitted using it.

[https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49453283/node-red-catching-error-node-red-contrib-composer/49454492?noredirect=1#comment85913466_49454492](url)

Please suggest if this can be solution and can be implemented in node-red composer nodes.

title: Remote connection node-red to hyperledger composer
body:
I have a node red instance and the hyperledger composer nodes installed on my virtual maschine (vm1).
On my second virtual maschine (vm2) I have deployed my hyperledger fabric business network with a single organization. I successful completed this tutorial 
https://hyperledger.github.io/composer/latest/tutorials/deploy-to-fabric-single-org

My fabric and composer services are running correctly. I have checked it with the composer REST API and can create new participants for example.

Now I am trying to connect my node-red to my busines network card "admin@tutorial-network" with the node "hyperledger-composer-out".

I have found this tutorial to connect node-red with composer. 
https://hyperledger.github.io/composer/unstable//tutorials/nodered-tutorial

When I try to create a new participant with some JSON Data, then an error message comes: Error: creating resource error Card not found: admin@tutorial-network Wrong Business Network Card specified.

My guess is  that node-red and hyperledger composer has to be on the same vm, so the network card can be found. It this correct?

How can node-red connect to composer without the REST API?

Is there any connection.json file available to specify my connection data to my hyperledger composer for the nodes in node-red?

something like this in the example of the fabric-dev-servers tools:

`{
    "type": "hlfv1",
    "orderers": [
       { "url" : "grpc://localhost:7050" }
    ],
    "ca": { "url": "http://localhost:7054", 
            "name": "ca.org1.example.com"
    },
    "peers": [
        {
            "requestURL": "grpc://localhost:7051",
            "eventURL": "grpc://localhost:7053"
        }
    ],
    "keyValStore": "${HOME}/.composer-credentials",
    "channel": "composerchannel",
    "mspID": "Org1MSP",
    "timeout": "300"
}`


or is the only working alternativeto connect node-red remotly with hyperledger over the REST-API?

Thanks for any answer!

title: Permission problems under Fedora27 with SELinux enabled
body:
When I'm following the tutorial:

 - https://hyperledger.github.io/composer/installing/development-tools.html
 - https://hyperledger.github.io/composer/tutorials/developer-tutorial.html

I have problems if SELinux is enabled (it's enabled by default on Fedora). As a workaround I can disable SELinux (`setenforce 0`) temporary during development with composer but this is not good.

I tried to see if changing the mount options in `docker-composer.yml` file by adding `:z` can help with that problem (https://www.projectatomic.io/blog/2015/06/using-volumes-with-docker-can-cause-problems-with-selinux/) but I have mixed success.

When I execute:
```
./startFabric.sh
./createPeerAdminCard.sh
```
now works but after some time my machine become unresponsive and need to reboot.

I'll continue to experiment and see if I can make it work without disabling SELinux.

title: [node-red-contrib-composer] Error when installing plugin using "Manage Palette"
body:
When I try to install the plugin using the "Manage Palette" feature of node-red the installation fails with a general error: "Error: stderr maxBuffer exceeded". The work-around for me was to install the plugin from the command inside the `.node-red` user settings. 

Note beyond, I am able to install other plugins via "Manage Palette" without problems. So, I don't think it is a general issue with my setup or the way I am using node-red.

Here is how to reproduce the issue:

* Install hyperledger as described in the [development guide](https://hyperledger.github.io/composer/installing/development-tools.html) - I am using Ubuntu LTS 16.04.3 (64-bit) and Node.js 8.9.1
* Allow unprivileged users for installing global npm packages  (this one is missing in the development guide, btw!) - I used [npm-g_nosudo](https://github.com/glenpike/npm-g_nosudo) for the setup
* Install node-red - Execute `npm install -g node-red` as  unprivileged user (no need for `--unsafe-perm` at this point)
* Start node-red - Execute `node-red` on the command line with the user account used to run hyperledger composer and fabric
* Try to install the plugin using "Manage Palette"

EDIT: Meanwhile, I have read the contribution guidelines of the main composer project. My understanding is that general support question should be asked on stack overflow or rocket chat first [which I have done now](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/47547554/q-error-when-installing-node-red-contrib-composer-using-manage-palette-feat). Do you want me to close the issue for now?

title: [node-red-contrib-composer] Add Get All /Resolve All feature as part of Retrieve action
body:
Using the "retrieve" action only allows for retrieving a single object instance of a given class and id. However, it would be nice to be able to retrieve _all instances of a given class_, as it is not (yet) possible to perform queries as part of the plugin. The client registry, i.e. the asset and participant registries, provide a method `getAll` and `resolveAll` to facilitate this.  

If you consider my feature request, I am happy to contribute on this. Please see my initial implementation which does a getAll / resolveAll if the "id"  is left empty as part of the node configuration.
https://github.com/hyperledger/composer-tools/compare/1b3e15f...mwittig:master

Please let me know what you think.

title: Helper for admin cards
body:
I've added a new script called createPeerAdminCard.sh. This can be run in the same manner as any of the scripts such as startFabric.sh

This though needs to use the composer-cli and there is a version check for this at the start. Also it uses jq that is a central part of ubuntu. (aside if thisisn't available then we just keep a copy of the certificate available)

This will create a peer admin card, and import it.

Therefore the typicaly dev flow would be


$ unzip fabric-dev-servers.zip
$ ./fabric-dev-servers/startFabric.sh
$ ./fabric-dev-servers/createPeerAdminCard.sh
$ composer network deploy --archiveFile ./packages/block-game-network/dist/bgn.bna --card PeerAdmin@hlfv1 -A admin -S 
$ composer card create -n block-game --file ./_cards/admin.card -j ~/.composer-connection-profiles/hlfv1/connection.json -u admin -s adminpw
$ composer card import --file ./_cards/admin.card 
$ composer card list        
$ composer network list --card admin@block-game

Resolves #2484

body:
There are many benefits for using Asciidoc over Markdown.
It is very similar to Markdown but allows using includes for instance.

This makes it easier to manage and easier to read for the users.

Github unfortunately does not render the includes yet but you can check it out when rendering the files locally in your browser using https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/asciidoctorjs-live-previe/iaalpfgpbocpdfblpnhhgllgbdbchmia

title: Remove HLFv0.6 from fabric-dev-servers
Deprecate the npm module 'node-red-contrib-hyperledger-composer' no longer used
body: Some confusion for Composer users about which node-red module to use.  At the time of writing, there are two sets of nodes out there: `node-red-contrib-hyperledger-composer` (old) and `node-red-contrib-composer` (correct and valid).  So Composer users should be using are `node-red-contrib-composer` only. As (apparently) you cannot 'unpublish' the module on https://www.npmjs.com/,  it should be deprecated instead.

title: fabric-dev-servers v0.6 fabric doesn't work anymore
body:
Looks like Hyperledger fabric have deleted the fabric-peer latest tag from the repository. A workaround for now is to
- in the directory where the fabric dev server was installed to
- change to the directory `fabric-scripts/hlfv0.6`
- edit the `docker-compose.yml` as follows

Original
```
vp0:
  image: hyperledger/fabric-peer
```
Change to
```
vp0:
  image: hyperledger/fabric-peer:x86_64-0.6.1-preview
```
save the file, return to the directory where the server was install to and run startFabric.sh

body: I have got the nodes installed locally, and I have gotten them all to work.  My understanding is that when the nodes try to establish a connection to the specified business network the code looks for the connection profile on the local file system.  With a regular node.js app I can use the COMPOSER_CONFIG environment variable rather than the local file system, but that doesn't seem to be possible with the current node-red nodes.  Also, I don't know how I would specify a valid (existing) location for KeyValStore with a node red application on Bluemix.
